item.title: Lawmakers in 18 states plan refuge bills for trans youth
item.author: Holly Ramer - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Lawmakers in 18 states plan refuge bills for trans youth
media:content.media:description: State Sen. Scott Wiener, D-San Francisco, discusses his proposed measure to provide legal refuge to displaced transgender youth and their families during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif., March 17, 2022. Democratic lawmakers in more than a dozen states are following California’s lead in seeking to offer legal refuge to displaced transgender youth and their families. The coordinated effort being announced Tuesday, May 3, by the LGBTQ Victory Institute and other advocates comes in response to recent actions taken in conservative states.

item.title: Wildfire in northeastern New Mexico expected to keep growing
item.author: Cedar Attanasio And Susan Montoya Bryan - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Wildfire in northeastern New Mexico expected to keep growing
media:content.media:credit: Hermits Peak fire in northern New Mexico on Sunday, May, 1, 2022. Thousands of firefighters are battling destructive wildfires in the Southwest as more residents are preparing to evacuate. (New Mexico National Guard via AP

In this photo provided by the New Mexico National Guard, a New Mexico National Guard Aviation UH-60 Black Hawk flies as part of firefighting efforts, dropping thousands of gallons of water with Bambi buckets from the air on the Calf Canyon

media:content.media:title: Wildfire in northeastern New Mexico expected to keep growing
media:content.media:credit: Hermits Peak fire in northern New Mexico on Sunday, May 1, 2022. Thousands of firefighters battled destructive wildfires in the Southwest as more residents prepared to evacuate in northern New Mexico where strong winds and dangerously dry conditions have made the blazes hard to contain. (New Mexico National Guard via AP
In this photo provided by the New Mexico National Guard, a New Mexico National Guard truck is ready to deliver potable water to communities in response to the Calf Canyon

item.title: Election 2022: Voters to decide Ohio’s heated Senate primary
item.author: Jill Colvin And Julie Carr Smyth - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Election 2022: Voters to decide Ohio’s heated Senate primary
media:content.media:description: Nan Whaley, former Mayor of Dayton, running for Ohio governor, speaks to reporters following a debate against John Cranley at Central State University in Wilberforce, Ohio, March 29, 2022. The first multi-state contest of the 2022 midterm election season takes place Tuesday, May 3. Ohio voters will decide governor nominees and one of the most contentious and expensive Republican U.S. Senate primaries in the nation.

item.title: Ukrainian refugees at camp in Mexico City await US action
item.author: Christopher Sherman - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Ukrainian refugees at camp in Mexico City await US action
media:content.media:description: Ukrainian refugees rest at a refugee camp in Utopia Park, Iztapalapa, Mexico City, Monday, May 2, 2022.

media:content.media:title: Ukrainian refugees at camp in Mexico City await US action

media:content.media:title: Ukrainian refugees at camp in Mexico City await US action
media:content.media:description: Mykhailo Pastenak, left, who is a Ukrainian-American and his girlfriend who is a Ukrainian refugee Maziana Hzyhozyshyn, arrive at a refugee camp at Utopia Park camp in Iztapalapa, Mexico City, Monday, May 2, 2022. Pastenak is helping Hzyhozyshyn through the refugee process so that she can make it to the United States faster.

item.title: Sydney man gets 12 years for murdering gay American in 1988
item.author: Rod Mcguirk - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Sydney man gets 12 years for murdering gay American in 1988
media:content.media:description: Steve Johnson, right, with his sisters, Terry, left, and Rebecca and his wife Rosemarie, second right, arrive at the Supreme Court in Sydney, Monday, May 2, 2022, for a sentencing hearing in the murder of Scott Johnson, Steve, Terry and Rebecca's brother. Scott White appeared in the New South Wales state Supreme Court for a sentencing hearing after he pleaded guilty in January to the murder of the Los Angeles-born Canberra resident Scott Johnson, whose death at the base of a North Head cliff was initially dismissed by police as suicide.

media:content.media:title: Sydney man gets 12 years for murdering gay American in 1988
media:content.media:description: Steve Johnson, brother of U.S. murder victim Scott Johnson, hugs his wife Rosemarie as they arrive at the Supreme Court in Sydney, Monday, May 2, 2022, for a sentencing hearing in the murder of Scott. Scott White appeared in the New South Wales state Supreme Court for a sentencing hearing after he pleaded guilty in January to the murder of the Los Angeles-born Canberra resident Scott Johnson, whose death at the base of a North Head cliff was initially dismissed by police as suicide.

media:content.media:title: Sydney man gets 12 years for murdering gay American in 1988
media:content.media:description: Steve Johnson, right, and his wife Rosemarie arrive at the Supreme Court in Sydney, Monday, May 2, 2022, for a sentencing hearing in the murder of Scott Johnson, Steve's brother. Scott White appeared in the New South Wales state Supreme Court for a sentencing hearing after he pleaded guilty in January to the murder of the Los Angeles-born Canberra resident Scott Johnson, whose death at the base of a North Head cliff was initially dismissed by police as suicide.

item.title: Report: Draft opinion suggests high court could overturn Roe
item.author: Mark Sherman And Zeke Miller - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Report: Draft opinion suggests high court could overturn Roe
media:content.media:description: A crowd of people gather outside the Supreme Court, Monday night, May 2, 2002 in Washington. A draft opinion circulated among Supreme Court justices suggests that earlier this year a majority of them had thrown support behind overturning the 1973 case Roe v. Wade that legalized abortion nationwide, according to a report published Monday night in Politico. It’s unclear if the draft represents the court’s final word on the matter. The Associated Press could not immediately confirm the authenticity of the draft Politico posted, which if verified marks a shocking revelation of the high court’s secretive deliberation process, particularly before a case is formally decided.

media:content.media:title: Report: Draft opinion suggests high court could overturn Roe
media:content.media:description: A crowd of people gather outside the Supreme Court, early Tuesday, May 3, 2022 in Washington. A draft opinion circulated among Supreme Court justices suggests that earlier this year a majority of them had thrown support behind overturning the 1973 case Roe v. Wade that legalized abortion nationwide, according to a report published Monday night in Politico. It's unclear if the draft represents the court's final word on the matter. The Associated Press could not immediately confirm the authenticity of the draft Politico posted, which if verified marks a shocking revelation of the high court's secretive deliberation process, particularly before a case is formally decided.

item.title: U.S. Supreme Court poised to strike down abortion rights, Politico reports
item.author: Greg Stohr - Bloomberg News
item.description: The U.S. Supreme Court is set to strike down Roe v. Wade, according to a draft majority opinion circulated inside the court, Politico reported.

media:content.media:title: U.S. Supreme Court poised to strike down abortion rights, Politico reports
media:content.media:description: Abortion rights advocates demonstrate in front of the U.S. Supreme Court on Dec. 1, 2021, in Washington, D.C.

item.title: AP source: WNBA to honor Griner with decal on teams’ floor
item.author: Doug Feinberg - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: AP source: WNBA to honor Griner with decal on teams’ floor
media:content.media:description: Phoenix Mercury center Brittney Griner pauses on the court during the second half of a WNBA basketball game against the Seattle Storm, Sept. 3, 2019, in Phoenix. Griner is easily the most prominent American citizen known to be jailed by a foreign government. Yet as a crucial hearing approaches next month, the case against her remains shrouded in mystery, with little clarity from the Russian prosecutors.

media:content.media:title: AP source: WNBA to honor Griner with decal on teams’ floor
media:content.media:description: Phoenix Mercury center Brittney Griner sits during the first half of Game 2 of basketball's WNBA Finals against the Chicago Sky, Wednesday, Oct. 13, 2021, in Phoenix. Griner is easily the most prominent American citizen known to be jailed by a foreign government. Yet as a crucial hearing approaches next month, the case against her remains shrouded in mystery, with little clarity from the Russian prosecutors.

item.title: Argentine nuns accuse archbishop, others of gender violence

item.title: Jury awards $15M in damages in UVA lacrosse player’s killing
item.author: Denise Lavoie - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Jury awards $15M in damages in UVA lacrosse player’s killing
media:content.media:description: In a March 8, 2009, photo, University of Virginia women?s lacrosse player Yeardley Love works with the ball in Charlottesville, Va. Nearly 12 years after Love was found dead, George Huguely, convicted of second-degree murder in her killing is headed back to court for a civil trial. Jury selection is expected in Charlottesville Circuit Court Monday, April 25, 2022 in a trial that will seek to hold George Huguely V liable in the death of Love.
media:content.media:credit: The Daily Progress, Andrew Shurtleff, File

media:content.media:title: Jury awards $15M in damages in UVA lacrosse player’s killing
media:content.media:description: Members of the Virginia women's lacrosse team hold candles during a memorial for teammate Yeardley Love at the school in Charlottesville, Va., Wednesday, May 5, 2010. Nearly 12 years after University of Virginia lacrosse player Yeardley Love was found dead, George Huguely, convicted of second-degree murder in her killing is headed back to court for a civil trial. Jury selection is expected in Charlottesville Circuit Court Monday, April 25, 2022 in a trial that will seek to hold George Huguely V liable in the death of Love.

media:content.media:title: Jury awards $15M in damages in UVA lacrosse player’s killing
media:content.media:description: Before the start of a women's lacrosse game between Virginia and Penn State, University of Virginia athletic director Craig Littlepage presents Yeardley Love's sister Lexie, left, and mother, Sharon, with a jersey with Yeardley's number Sunday, March 6, 2011, in Charlottesville, Va. Nearly 12 years after Love was found dead, George Huguely, convicted of second-degree murder in her killing is headed back to court for a civil trial. Jury selection is expected in Charlottesville Circuit Court Monday, April 25, 2022 in a trial that will seek to hold George Huguely V liable in the death of Love.
media:content.media:credit: The Daily Progress via AP, File

media:content.media:title: Jury awards $15M in damages in UVA lacrosse player’s killing
media:content.media:description: A person holds a program for the funeral of slain University of Virginia lacrosse player Yeardley Love in Baltimore, Md., on Saturday, May 8, 2010. Nearly 12 years after Love was found dead, George Huguely, convicted of second-degree murder in her killing is headed back to court for a civil trial. Jury selection is expected in Charlottesville Circuit Court Monday, April 25, 2022 in a trial that will seek to hold George Huguely V liable in the death of Love.

media:content.media:title: Jury awards $15M in damages in UVA lacrosse player’s killing
media:content.media:description: In this Wednesday Aug 22, 2012 file photo, George Huguely V is escorted to Charlottesville Circuit Court for a hearing in Charlottesville, Va. Nearly 12 years after University of Virginia lacrosse player Yeardley Love was found dead, Huguely, convicted of second-degree murder in her killing is headed back to court for a civil trial. Jury selection is expected in Charlottesville Circuit Court Monday, April 25, 2022 in a trial that will seek to hold George Huguely V liable in the death of Love.
media:content.media:credit: The Daily Progress via AP, File

media:content.media:title: Jury awards $15M in damages in UVA lacrosse player’s killing
media:content.media:description: University of Virginia men's lacrosse player George Huguely, a fourth-year student from Chevy Chase, Md., is shown in a booking photo provided by the Charlottsville Police Department. Nearly 12 years after University of Virginia lacrosse player Yeardley Love was found dead, Huguely, convicted of second-degree murder in her killing is headed back to court for a civil trial. Jury selection is expected in Charlottesville Circuit Court Monday, April 25, 2022 in a trial that will seek to hold George Huguely V liable in the death of Love.

item.title: Rights groups criticize El Salvador’s mass gang roundups
item.author: The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Rights groups criticize El Salvador’s mass gang roundups
media:content.media:description: El Salvador's President Nayib Bukele speaks to the press at Mexico's National Palace after meeting with the President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador in Mexico City, March 12, 2019. El Salvador’s president has threatened Tuesday, April 6, 2022, that he will cut off food for imprisoned members of street gangs if they “unleash a wave of crimes.

item.title: Judge lets Tulsa Race Massacre reparations lawsuit proceed
item.author: Ken Miller - The Associated Press

media:content.media:title: Judge lets Tulsa Race Massacre reparations lawsuit proceed
media:content.media:description: Tiffany Crutcher, left, and U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee speak to the media before a hearing at Tulsa County Courthouse, Monday, May 2, 2022, in Tulsa, Okla. A judge ruled Monday that a lawsuit can proceed that seeks reparations for survivors and descendants of victims of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre.

media:content.media:title: Judge lets Tulsa Race Massacre reparations lawsuit proceed
media:content.media:description: People wait for a hearing at the Tulsa County Courthouse, Monday, May 2, 2022, in Tulsa, Okla. A judge ruled Monday that a lawsuit can proceed that seeks reparations for survivors and descendants of victims of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre.

media:content.media:title: Judge lets Tulsa Race Massacre reparations lawsuit proceed
media:content.media:description: Lessie Benningfield Randle, 107, a survivor of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre, attends a hearing at the Tulsa County Courthouse, Monday, May 2, 2022, in Tulsa, Okla. A judge ruled Monday that a lawsuit can proceed that seeks reparations for survivors and descendants of victims of the massacre.

media:content.media:title: Judge lets Tulsa Race Massacre reparations lawsuit proceed
media:content.media:description: Viola Fletcher, 107, a survivor of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre, attends a hearing at the Tulsa County Courthouse, Monday, May 2, 2022, in Tulsa, Okla. A judge ruled Monday that a lawsuit can proceed that seeks reparations for survivors and descendants of victims of the massacre.

media:content.media:title: Judge lets Tulsa Race Massacre reparations lawsuit proceed

A judge ruled Monday that a lawsuit can proceed that seeks reparations for survivors and descendants of victims of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre.

media:content.media:title: Judge lets Tulsa Race Massacre reparations lawsuit proceed
media:content.media:description: Hughes Van Ellis, 101, foreground left, and Lessie Benningfield Randle, 107, right, survivors of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre, are wheeled outside a courtroom at the Tulsa County Courthouse, Monday, May 2, 2022, in Tulsa, Okla. A judge ruled Monday that a lawsuit can proceed that seeks reparations for survivors and descendants of victims of the massacre.

media:content.media:title: Judge lets Tulsa Race Massacre reparations lawsuit proceed
media:content.media:description: Attorney Damario Solomon Simmons, center, attends a hearing at the Tulsa County Courthouse, Monday, May 2, 2022, in Tulsa, Okla. A judge ruled Monday that a lawsuit can proceed that seeks reparations for survivors and descendants of victims of the massacre.

media:content.media:title: Judge lets Tulsa Race Massacre reparations lawsuit proceed
media:content.media:description: Attorney Damario Solomon Simmons, center, attends a hearing at the Tulsa County Courthouse, Monday, May 2, 2022, in Tulsa, Okla. A judge ruled Monday that a lawsuit can proceed that seeks reparations for survivors and descendants of victims of the massacre.
